We argue that by using the historical record, such as informationabout the motivation of policy makers or important developments in the worldeconomy, one can identify times when policy moved for reasons unrelated to thestate of real output and times when other factors were not acting to move realoutput. Such times, we suggested, provide the clearest evidence of theeffects of policy.Independence of Policy Changes.
